node.title: Shhh! Is noise keeping us from thinking?
node.description: Noises, like the saturation of urban life, can keep our bodies in a state of alarm or help develop our brains, neurologist Nina Kraus says. Audio

node.title: Hundreds of sightings of rare Hector's and Māui dolphins reported
node.description: Hundreds of Hector's and Māui dolphins have been sighted around Aotearoa this summer, with people keeping an eye out for the distinctive markings and rounded dorsal fins of the endangered cetaceans.

node.title: Three waters working group stymied by government bottom lines
node.description: Three waters feedback going to the minister on Monday seems unlikely to sway the government, whose latest model appears to fall short of its own demands.

node.title: Interislander resumes sailing after Covid-19 halt to service
node.description: The Interislander passenger ferry will sail tonight after earlier trips were cancelled due to 55 staff contracting covid-19 or isolating.

node.title: Transcript: U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Filippo Grandi, the U.N. high commissioner for refugees, that aired Sunday, March 6, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: 1.5 million Ukrainians have fled Russian invasion, U.N. commissioner says
node.description: "If I think of past decades, I cannot think in Europe of a faster exodus of people not since the end of the second world war," Grandi said.

node.title: Visa and Mastercard suspend operations in Russia over Ukraine invasion
node.description: Since the invasion of Ukraine, the value of the Russian currency, the ruble, has plunged by more than a third to a record low.

node.title: Brilliant Kiwis win Davis Cup tie
node.description: Newly appointed Davis Cup captain Kelly Evernden has his first win in charge of the New Zealand team after the Kiwis beat Uruguay 3-1.

node.title: Schiff signals "strong bipartisan support" for banning Russian oil and gas
node.description: "There is strong support to show solidarity with Ukraine, but also to make sure that American dollars aren't supporting the Russian war machine in any way," Schiff said.

node.title: Transcript: Ambassador Kurt Volker on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Kurt Volker, the former ambassador to NATO and special representative for Ukraine, that aired Sunday, March 6, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Warne had 'seen a doctor about his heart' before his sudden death
node.description: Australian cricket great Shane Warne had experienced chest pains prior to his death in Thailand and had a history of asthma and some heart issues, according to Thai Police.

node.title: Transcript: Representative Adam Schiff on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Democratic Representative Adam Schiff of California that aired Sunday, March 6, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Biden team in Venezuela as U.S. seeks to split country from Russia
node.description: The visit is yet another example of a geopolitical shift underway across the globe in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

node.title: John Dickerson on Zelensky's leadership, and on making courage contagious
node.description: The Ukrainian president's defiance against the invading Russian army has done more than just help protect his country; it has helped bolster the strength of other democracies much older than Ukraine's.

node.title: Behind the scenes of the Pfizer vaccine
node.description: Dr. Albert Bourla, the pharmaceutical giant's chairman and CEO, talks about vaccine hesitancy, COVID misinformation, and the development of his company's coronavirus vaccine, an effort he writes about in the book "Moonshot."

node.title: Ukraine vs. Russia: A modern-day David vs. Goliath story
node.description: The Biblical tale of overcoming a seemingly insurmountable adversary is evoked by Zelensky's defiant stand against Putin, whose military is attempting to crush his neighboring country.

node.title: Dolly Parton and James Patterson on "Run, Rose, Run"
node.description: Two of the biggest names in their respective fields not only share a cause, but also the byline of a new novel – an artistic collaboration that sparked a blooming friendship.

node.title: Samuel L. Jackson loves his job
node.description: The Oscar-nominated actor who has appeared in more than 150 films talks about his love of popcorn movies, the business of Hollywood, and his new TV miniseries, "The Last Days of Ptolemy Grey."

node.title: Lessons from the 1918 Spanish Flu epidemic
node.description: The influenza pandemic that killed 675,000 Americans a century ago is often referred to as the "forgotten flu." Also forgotten: lessons it might have taught us for how to deal with the cost, in lives, of COVID-19.

node.title: How far will Putin go – and how far will America go to stop him?
node.description: No one can possibly know for sure what Russia's leader, who has launched an invasion of neighboring Ukraine, may do next. But how might Americans be forced to sacrifice in hopes of saving Ukraine's fragile young democracy?

node.title: Blinken: NATO members have "green light" to send fighter jets to Ukraine
node.description: "Winning a battle is not the same thing as winning a war. Taking the city is not the same thing as capturing the hearts and minds of Ukrainians," Blinken said.

node.title: Ukrainian civilians race to evacuate under 11-hour cease-fire
node.description: Authorities prepared Sunday for a second attempt to evacuate civilians​ from a southern city pounded by a week-long Russian attack.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 15,161 new community cases, 618 in hospital, one death
node.description: There are 15,161 new community cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand today, with 610 people now in hospital, the Ministry of Health reports.

node.title: Trump renews NATO criticism after Russia's invasion of Ukraine
node.description: The former president spoke to top GOP donors Saturday night.

node.title: Climate change, Covid-19 loom over Alaska's 50th annual sled dog race
node.description: Forty-nine mushers and their teams of huskies trotted through Alaska's largest city on Saturday to start the 50th annual running of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, an event transformed by climate…

node.title: Christ Church Cathedral restoration still on track for completion in 2027
node.description: Progress is steady for the Christ Church Cathedral restoration, but locals cannot expect to see a finished building any time soon.

node.title: Name of victim in Hamilton homicide investigation released
node.description: Police have opened a homicide investigation after a man died at a house in Huntington last night.

node.title: Death toll in Australian flooding hits 17
node.description: Sydney braced for more rain on Sunday after being drenched by heavy downpours over the past week, as the death toll from flooding across the eastern part of the country reached 17.

node.title: Siege of Mariupol: Thousands trapped as Russia ignores ceasefire
node.description: Russian forces continued to shell the Ukrainian city of Mariupol on Saturday, despite agreeing to a ceasefire just hours earlier - throwing an attempted mass evacuation of civilians into chaos.

node.title: Russia announces limited ceasefire in Ukraine for civilian evacuations
node.description: Russia said its forces had stopped firing near two Ukrainian cities to allow safe passage to civilians fleeing fighting, but was continuing its broad offensive.
